entry.title: installing Psi4 and Forte
entry.content:
This tutorial provides a step-by-step guide for installing the quantum chemistry packages Psi4 and Forte in Windows 11 WSL2.

  • Psi4: https://github.com/psi4/psi4
  • Forte: https://github.com/evangelistalab/forte

This guide heavily references from Francesco‚Äôs psi4/ambit/forte setup (Mac BigSur 11.6.1, Dec. 2021)

1. Update Ubuntu Packages

1.1 Launch WSL

In Windows PowerShell or CMD:

wsl

Enter root mode:

sudo -i

1.2 Change Ubuntu Mirror (Optional)

If network access is slow, consider switching to a faster mirror.

Backup:

cp /etc/apt/sources.list /etc/apt/sources.list.backup

Replace the content of /etc/apt/sources.list with a mirror matching your Ubuntu version.

For example, Tsinghua Open Source Mirror

1.3 Update Packages

apt update
apt upgrade
apt autoremove

Install development tools:

apt install build-essential gfortran

Install spf13-vim (optional):

curl https://j.mp/spf13-vim3 -L > spf13-vim.sh && sh spf13-vim.sh

2. Install CUDA Toolkit (Optional)

Requires NVIDIA driver installed in Windows.

Follow instructions from NVIDIA website.https://developer.nvidia.com/cuda-downloads

Example (WSL-Ubuntu, deb network):

wget https://developer.download.nvidia.com/compute/cuda/repos/wsl-ubuntu/x86_64/cuda-keyring_1.1-1_all.deb
sudo dpkg -i cuda-keyring_1.1-1_all.deb
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get -y install cuda-toolkit-12-6

Verify installation:

nvidia-smi

3. Install Intel oneAPI (Optional)

Install Intel Base Toolkit and HPC Toolkit via APT:https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/developer/tools/oneapi/base-toolkit-download.html

sudo apt update
sudo apt install -y gpg-agent wget
wget -O- https://apt.repos.intel.com/intel-gpg-keys/GPG-PUB-KEY-INTEL-SW-PRODUCTS.PUB | gpg ‚Äìdearmor | sudo tee /usr/share/keyrings/oneapi-archive-keyring.gpg > /dev/null
echo ‚Äúdeb [signed-by=/usr/share/keyrings/oneapi-archive-keyring.gpg] https://apt.repos.intel.com/oneapi all main‚Äù | sudo tee /etc/apt/sources.list.d/oneAPI.list
sudo apt update
sudo apt install intel-basekit
sudo apt install intel-hpckit
A sucessful installation should generate the `/opt/intel/oneapi` folder.

Set up the environment:

source /opt/intel/oneapi/setvars.sh

Optionally, add the following to ~/.bashrc so that the variables are automatically loaded every time starting WSL:

. /opt/intel/oneapi/setvars.sh

4. Configure Python Environment

4.1 Install Miniconda

wget https://repo.anaconda.com/miniconda/Miniconda3-latest-Linux-x86_64.sh
bash Miniconda3-latest-Linux-x86_64.sh

4.2 Add conda-forge Channel

Edit ~/.condarc:

channels:
  - conda-forge
  - defaults
It is also possible to specify channel mirrors, e.g., Anaconda ËΩØ‰ª∂‰ªìÂ∫ì

4.3 Create forte.yml

name: forte
dependencies:
  - python=3.12
  - pip
  - cmake
  - clang-format
  - numpy
  - scipy
  - boost
  - hdf5
  - yaml
  - jupyter
  - eigen
  - pytest
  - pydantic
  - pint
  - pybind11
  - pyyaml
  - pythreejs
  - libint

Create environment:

conda env create -f forte.yml
conda activate forte

Add activation command conda activate forte to ~/.bashrc if desired.

5. Install Forte (Non-developer)

The easiest way to install forte is from conda:

conda install conda-forge::forte

Developers may need to compile Forte manually (see below).

6. Install Ambit (Developer)

git clone https://github.com/jturney/ambit.git
cd ambit
mkdir build && cd build
cmake .. -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$HOME/src/ambit-install \
         -DCMAKE_C_COMPILER=icx \
         -DCMAKE_CXX_COMPILER=icpx
make -j20
make install
Please search for 'ghproxy' on the internet if you encounter internet issue when cloning the repository.

Add to ~/.bashrc:

export PYTHONPATH=$HOME/src/ambit-install/lib:$PYTHONPATH
export AMBITPATH=$HOME/src/ambit-install

7. Install block2-preview (Optional for DMRG)

git clone https://github.com/block-hczhai/block2-preview.git
cd block2-preview
mkdir build && cd build
cmake .. -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$HOME/src/block2-install \
         -DUSE_MKL=ON \
         -DBUILD_CLIB=ON \
         -DLARGE_BOND=ON \
         -DMPI=OFF \
         -DCMAKE_C_COMPILER=icx \
         -DCMAKE_CXX_COMPILER=icpx
make -j20
make install
If you see the error message `icpx: error: Use of ‚Äò-qopenmp‚Äô recommended over ‚Äò-fopenmp‚Äô [-Werror,-Wrecommended-option]`, you may replace `‚Äìfopenmp` to `-qopenmp` in `CMakeLists.txt`.

8. Install Psi4 from Source (Developer)

Install dependencies:

conda install libxc libecpint dkh gau2grid qcelemental qcengine optking

Clone source:

git clone https://github.com/psi4/psi4.git
cd psi4
mkdir build
cd build

Configure:

cmake .. -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=$HOME/src/psi4-install \
         -DENABLE_dkh=ON \
         -DENABLE_ambit=ON \
         -DENABLE_ecpint=ON \
         -DMAX_AM_ERI=8 \
         -Dpsi4_CXX_STANDARD=20 \
         -DCMAKE_CXX_STANDARD=20 \
         -Dambit_DIR=$HOME/src/ambit-install/share/cmake/ambit \
         -DCMAKE_C_COMPILER=icx \
         -DCMAKE_CXX_COMPILER=icpx \
         -DCMAKE_Fortran_COMPILER=gfortran

Compile:

make -j20
make install

If Eigen error fatal error: ‚Äòeigen3/Eigen/Core‚Äô file not found occurs, you may install a new eigen via sudo apt install libeigen3-dev. Then, remove CMakeCache.txt and CMakeFiles and reconfigure with -DEigen3_DIR=/usr/share/eigen3/cmake.

Add environment variables to ~/.bashrc:Please check https://psicode.org/psi4manual/1.1.0/build_planning

export PSI4OBJ=$HOME/src/psi4/build
export PSI4INS=$HOME/src/psi4-install
export PSIDATADIR=$PSI4INS/share/psi4
export PSI_SCRATCH=/tmp/scratch/psi4
export PYTHONPATH=$PSI4OBJ/stage/lib:$PYTHONPATH
export PATH=$PSI4OBJ/stage/bin:$PATH

Test:

cd $HOME/src/psi4/tests/scf1
psi4

9. Install Forte (Developer)

9.1 Clone:

git clone https://github.com/evangelistalab/forte.git
cd forte

9.2 Compile

9.2.1 Compile via setup.py (Recommended)

Create setup.cfg:

[CMakeBuild]
ambitpath=$HOME/src/ambit-install
cmake_config_options=-DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug -DENABLE_block2=ON -DCMAKE_PREFIX_PATH=$HOME/src/block2-install/share/cmake/block2

You need to replace $HOME to full path in the above lines.

Then execute:

python setup.py develop

9.2.2 Manual CMake build using psi4 --plugin-compile

Create compile-forte.sh:

#! /bin/bash
# Modify the following parameters
ambit_dir=$HOME/src/ambit-install/share/cmake/ambit
block2_dir=$HOME/src/block2-install/share/cmake/block2
srcdir=$HOME/src/forte
build_type=Debug
# Run cmake
cd $srcdir
rm -rf CMakeFiles CMakeCache.txt cmake_install.cmake
cmake_psi4=`psi4 ‚Äìplugin-compile`
$cmake_psi4 -Dambit_DIR=$ambit_dir -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=$build_type -DMAX_DET_ORB=128 -DENABLE_block2=ON -Dblock2_DIR=$block2_dir
# Compile
make -j20

Please replace relevant paths.

Execute:

bash compile-forte.sh

Set environment variables in ~/.bashrc:

PYTHONPATH=$HOME/src/forte:$PYTHONPATH

9.3 Test

cd $HOME/src/forte/tests/method
python run_forte_tests.py --type short

üéâ Hooray! You compiled Forte successfully!
entry.summary: a step-by-step guide to installing Psi4 and Forte

entry.title: setting up WSL2
entry.content:
This tutorial describes how to set up WSL2 (Windows Subsystem for Linux) on Windows 11 Home Edition as in September 2024. The guide is adapted and consolidated from several online resources.

Check these blogs (in Chinese):

  1. Windows 11 Êê≠Âª∫ WSL2 ËøêË°åÁéØÂ¢ÉÔºà2024Ôºâ- CSDNÂçöÂÆ¢ https://blog.csdn.net/qq_39316962/article/details/139927197
  2. ‰∏∫‰ªÄ‰πàWin11Êâæ‰∏çÂà∞Hyper-VÔºüÊÄé‰πàËß£ÂÜ≥Ôºühttps://www.abackup.com/enterprise-backup/win11-cannot-find-hyper-v-6540.html

1. Enable Virtualization and Required Features

1.1 Install Hyper-V (Windows 11 Home Only)

Windows 11 Professional users can skip this step.

  1. Create a file named win11-home-hyperv.bat
  2. Add the following content: 
    pushd "%~dp0"
dir /b %SystemRoot%\servicing\Packages\*Hyper-V*.mum >hyper-v.txt
for /f %%i in ('findstr /i . hyper-v.txt 2^>nul') do dism /online /norestart /add-package:"%SystemRoot%\servicing\Packages\%%i"
del hyper-v.txt
Dism /online /enable-feature /featurename:Microsoft-Hyper-V-All /LimitAccess /ALL
  3. Right-click the file and run as Administrator.

1.2 Enable Windows Features

  1. Open Control Panel
  2. Go to Programs ‚Üí Turn Windows features on or off
  3. Enable:
    • Hyper-V
    • Windows Subsystem for Linux
    • Virtual Machine Platform
  4. Click OK and restart your computer.

2. Install WSL2

2.1 Open PowerShell or Command Prompt

Check available WSL commands:

wsl --help

2.2 Update WSL and Set Default Version

wsl --update
wsl --set-default-version 2

2.3 List Available Linux Distributions

wsl --list --online

2.4 Install Ubuntu (Recommended: 22.04 LTS)

wsl --install -d Ubuntu-22.04

By default, Linux will be installed on the system drive (C:).

2.5 Move Ubuntu to Another Drive (Optional)

If your C: drive has limited space, you can migrate the distribution. Here we move Ubuntu-22.04 to D: drive and rename it to Ubuntu-22.04-D.

2.5.1: Check and Stop Running Distributions

wsl -l -v
wsl --terminate Ubuntu-22.04

2.5.2: Export the Distribution

wsl --export Ubuntu-22.04 D:\ubuntu2204-export.tar

2.5.3: Unregister the Original Distribution

wsl --unregister Ubuntu-22.04

2.5.4: Import to a New Location

wsl --import Ubuntu-22.04-D D:\Ubuntu-22.04 D:\ubuntu2204-export.tar --version 2

After completion:

  • You can open Ubuntu-22.04-D from the PowerShell terminal.
  • Linux files are accessible through Windows File Explorer.

3. Configure Proxy Networking (Optional)

If you need proxy access:

3.1 Install Clash

Install Clash and enable:

  • Proxy configuration
  • Allow LAN option

3.2 Configure .wslconfig

Create a file:

C:\Users\<your-username>\.wslconfig

Add:

[experimental]
autoMemoryReclaim=gradual
networkingMode=mirrored
dnsTunneling=true
firewall=true
autoProxy=true

3.3 Close WSL

wsl --shutdown

3.4 Test Connection

Start a new WSL and test connection:

wget www.google.com

If successful, your proxy configuration is working correctly.
entry.summary: a step-by-step guide to installing WSL2 on Windows 11 Home Edition

entry.title: cluster witout internet connection
entry.content:
Note: CentOS 7 has reached end-of-life (EOL). These instructions are intended for maintaining legacy systems.

This document records procedures for:

  • Accessing the internet from an offline server via SSH tunnel
  • Fixing the CentOS 7 repository issue
  • Installing Environment Modules from source

1. Internet Connection via SSH Tunnel

If server A does not have direct internet access, but another server does, we can tunnel traffic through SSH using dynamic port forwarding. Although we use CentOS 7 here, the approach in this section also works for Rocky Linux 8.

References:

  • https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/157743/tunnel-yum-traffic-through-another-server-via-ssh
  • https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/111972/connect-to-the-internet-on-a-vpn-connected-server-without-internet

1.1 Configure YUM to Use Proxy

Edit:

/etc/yum.conf

Add:

proxy=socks5h://localhost:1080

1.2 Establish SSH Tunnel

ssh -D 1080 YOUR_USER@YOUR_SERVER_WITH_FULL_WEB_ACCESS

This creates a local SOCKS5 proxy on port 1080. Keep this terminal open.

1.3 Test the Connection

curl --socks5 127.0.0.1:1080 http://www.baidu.com

If successful, internet traffic is being routed through the SSH tunnel.

1.4 Configure Proxy for Conda and Git

Edit ~/.condarc:

proxy_servers:
  http: socks5://127.0.0.1:1080
  https: socks5://127.0.0.1:1080

Edit ~/.gitconfig:

[http]
    proxy = socks5://127.0.0.1:1080
[https]
    proxy = socks5://127.0.0.1:1080

2. Fix: mirrorlist.centos.org No Longer Available

Since CentOS 7 is EOL, the default mirrorlist no longer resolves.

Reference:

  • https://serverfault.com/questions/1161816/mirrorlist-centos-org-no-longer-resolve

2.1 Switch to Vault Repository

sed -i 's/mirror.centos.org/vault.centos.org/g' /etc/yum.repos.d/*.repo
sed -i 's/^#.*baseurl=http/baseurl=http/g' /etc/yum.repos.d/*.repo
sed -i 's/^mirrorlist=http/#mirrorlist=http/g' /etc/yum.repos.d/*.repo

These lines essentially replace mirror.centos.org to vault.centos.org in /etc/yum.repos.d/CentOS-Base.repo.

2.2 Update System

yum update

3. Install Environment Modules

Environment Modules allow dynamic modification of shell environments, which is useful for managing compilers, MPI, and scientific software.

Documentation:

  • https://modules.readthedocs.io/en/stable/INSTALL.html

3.1 Download Source (with SSH tunnel)

curl --socks5 127.0.0.1:1080 -LJO \
https://github.com/cea-hpc/modules/releases/download/v5.4.0/modules-5.4.0.tar.gz

3.2 Extract

tar xfz modules-5.4.0.tar.gz
cd modules-5.4.0

3.3 Compile and Install

./configure --prefix=/usr/share/Modules \
            --modulefilesdir=/usr/share/Modules/modulefiles
make
make install

3.4 Enable Modules at Shell Startup

ln -s /usr/share/Modules/init/profile.sh /etc/profile.d/modules.sh
ln -s /usr/share/Modules/init/profile.csh /etc/profile.d/modules.csh

Log out and back in, or run:

source /etc/profile.d/modules.sh

3.5 Test Modules

module sh-to-mod bash example/source-script-in-modulefile/foo-1.2/foo-setup.sh arg1 > modulefiles/foo/1.2

module avail
module load foo/1.2

Final Remarks

These procedures are primarily for maintaining legacy CentOS 7 cluster nodes.

For new deployments, consider:

  • Rocky Linux or AlmaLinux
  • A modern workload manager (e.g., SLURM)
  • Lmod instead of classic Environment Modules

Maintaining clear documentation is essential for long-term cluster stability.
entry.summary: setting up cluster 18: SSH tunneling, CentOS 7 vault fix, and environment modules installation

entry.title: installing CentOS 6 on a cluster node

link.title: installing CentOS 6 on a cluster node

entry.content:
Warning: CentOS 6 has reached end-of-life (EOL). This guide is preserved for legacy cluster maintenance only.

This document records the procedure for installing CentOS 6 on a computing node in cluster 10/11, including network configuration, InfiniBand firmware, and queue system setup.

1. Prepare Installation Media (macOS example)

Follow the official CentOS guide for creating a bootable USB drive.https://docs.centos.org/en-US/centos/install-guide/Making_Media_USB_Mac

diskutil list
diskutil unmountDisk /dev/diskN      # replace N with disk number
sudo dd if=/path/to/image.iso of=/dev/rdiskN bs=1m
# Press Ctrl + t to check progress
diskutil eject /dev/diskN

Note: /dev/rdiskN is faster than /dev/diskN.

2. Install CentOS

Choose Software Development or Server installation.

Recommended disk partitioning (300 GB in total):

  • /boot: 500 MB (ext3)
  • swap: 64 GB
  • /: remaining space

3. Disable SELinux

In file /etc/selinux/config, change SELINUX=enforcing to SELINUX=disabled.

4. Configure Network

Edit the following files and compare with other nodes:

/etc/sysconfig/network
/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-em1
/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-ib0
/etc/hosts
/etc/hosts.equiv

Additional steps to clear SSH cache:

  1. Delete /root/.ssh/known_hosts on the management node.
  2. Copy /root/.ssh from the management node to the compute node.
  3. Restart network: service network restart or /etc/init.d/network restart.

5. Create Local YUM Repository from ISO

Mount the ISO:

mount -o loop,ro centos6.iso /mnt/centos6-iso

Create /etc/yum.repos.d/os.repo:

[os]
name=CentOS6-OS
baseurl=file:///mnt/centos6-iso
gpgcheck=1
enabled=1
gpgkey=file:///etc/pki/rpm-gpg/RPM-GPG-KEY-CentOS-6

Test:

yum list

6. Install InfiniBand Firmware (Mellanox ConnectX-3)

Please check the following blogs first:

  1. https://blog.csdn.net/sinat_36458870/article/details/116596019
  2. https://blog.csdn.net/force_eagle/article/details/46728665

6.1 Install dependencies

yum install tcl-devel tk-devel libmnl-devel

Install Mellanox Firmware Tools (MFT) from the official website.https://network.nvidia.com/products/adapter-software/firmware-tools In particular, we need mft-4.14.2.

6.2 Identify HCA firmware

Here we follow the Nvidia support page.https://www.mellanox.com/support/firmware/identification

> [root@node3_ib ~]# lspci | grep Mell
> 03:00.0 Network controller [0207]: Mellanox Technologies MT27500 Family [ConnectX-3]
> [root@node3_ib ~]# flint -d 03:00.0 q
> Image type: FS2
> FW Version: 2.40.5048
> FW Release Date: 5.3.2017
> Product Version: 02.40.50.48
> Rom Info: type=PXE version=3.4.746 devid=4099
> Device ID: 4099
> ‚Ä¶
> PSID: DEL0A20000018

Record the PSID value, that is, DEL0A20000018.

6.3 Find firmware on Mellanox website

Since the PSID is from Dell, we need to download the firmware from https://www.mellanox.com/support/firmware/dell?mtag=oem_firmware_download. A complete list can be found in the Mellanox website.https://www.mellanox.com/support/firmware/firmware-downloads

6.4 Start MST

mst start
mst status

6.5 Burn firmware

flint -d /dev/mst/mt4099_pciconf0 -i fw-ConnectX3-xxxxx.bin burn

Reboot afterward.

6.6 Install OFED driver

The driver can be downloaded from the Mellanox website.https://www.mellanox.com/products/infiniband-drivers/linux/mlnx_ofed Specifically, we need 4.1-1.0.2.0 for CentOS 6.5 and install it:

MLNX_OFED_LINUX-4.1-1.0.2.0-rhel6.5-x86_64/mlnxofedinstall

Restart OpenIB:

/etc/init.d/openibd restart

Verify:

ofed_info | head
ibstat

7. Configure SGE (Sun Grid Engine)

All binaries are available on the IO node. Only /home and /backup need to be mounted.

  • Create /backup
  • Modify /etc/fstab
  • Mount, run, and copy settings:
mount -a
export SGE_ROOT=/home/jointforce
cd /home/jointforce
./install_execd
cp /home/jointforce/default/common/settings* /etc/profile.d/

8. Disable iptables

service iptables save
service iptables stop
chkconfig iptables off

9. Configure NIS

Edit:

/etc/sysconfig/network
/etc/yp.conf
/etc/nsswitch.conf

Follow internal documentation or existing cluster configuration.This blog may be useful: http://cn.linux.vbird.org/linux_server/0430nis.php

10. Install EasyCluster

  • Copy /opt/easycluster from an existing node.
  • Add /opt/easycluster/background/easy_c in /etc/rc.local.
  • Start EasyCluster.

11. Configure the system-wide environment

Copy necessary configuration files to /etc/profile.d/.

Final Remarks

This setup reflects legacy cluster configuration practices. For new deployments, consider using a modern distribution (e.g., Rocky Linux) and contemporary workload managers such as SLURM.

Cluster configuration should be documented carefully and updated whenever changes are made.

entry.title: writing scientific papers
entry.content:
Writing is an essential part of research. Clear scientific writing reflects clear scientific thinking.

A well-written paper does not merely report results ‚Äî it explains motivation, methodology, limitations, and significance in a way that allows others to understand and reproduce your work.

Below are resources and practical advice to help you develop strong scientific writing skills.

General Advice on Writing

Notes by Professor David Sherrill

https://vergil.chemistry.gatech.edu/resources#Scientific-Writing

This note is concise, practical, and written specifically for computational chemists. Do not just read them once ‚Äî revisit them while drafting your own manuscript.

Whitesides‚Äô Group: ‚ÄúWriting a Paper‚Äù

DOI: 10.1002/adma.200400767

This classic article provides high-level guidance on structuring a scientific paper:

  • Tell a clear story.
  • Make the logical progression obvious.
  • Respect the reader‚Äôs time.
  • Separate results from interpretation carefully.

If you internalize the principles in this article, your writing will improve dramatically.

Learning LaTeX - Overleaf LaTeX Tutorials

https://www.overleaf.com/learn/latex/Learn_LaTeX_in_30_minutes

A practical way to learn LaTeX is to start from real journal templates (ACS, AIP, PCCP, etc.) on Overleaf and modify them.

You should learn:

  • Basic document structure
  • Equations and alignment environments
  • Cross-referencing and labels
  • Bibliography management (BibTeX or BibLaTeX)
  • Figure and table placement
  • Packages commonly used in chemistry manuscripts

LaTeX is not optional. It is the standard tool for professional scientific writing.

Creating Better Figures - ‚ÄúTen Simple Rules for Better Figures‚Äù

DOI: 10.1371/journal.pcbi.1003833

This article discusses principles such as:

  • Clarity over decoration
  • Consistent typography
  • Appropriate color usage
  • Informative captions
  • Reproducibility

You should also examine the plotting code provided by the authors and reflect on how figures are constructed programmatically.

A good figure should:

  • Be understandable without reading the full paper.
  • Clearly communicate the key message.
  • Avoid unnecessary graphical elements.

In computational chemistry, figures often include:

  • Energy plots
  • Convergence curves
  • Potential energy surfaces
  • Orbital visualizations
  • Error analysis across methods

Please design them carefully.

How to Practice Scientific Writing

Reading advice is not enough. Writing improves only through practice.

Here is how you should train yourself:

  1. Rewrite paragraphs from well-written papers in your own words.
  2. Summarize a paper in one page.
  3. Write short technical reports for your computational results.
  4. Draft internal group reports even if they are not for publication.
  5. Ask for feedback and revise.

Expect to revise your manuscript multiple times. Strong papers are rewritten, not written once.

Common Mistakes to Avoid

  • Writing long sentences with unclear logical structure.
  • Mixing results with speculation.
  • Overusing jargon without explanation.
  • Presenting equations without defining symbols.
  • Including figures that do not support a clear message.
  • Ignoring reproducibility details (basis sets, thresholds, convergence criteria, etc.).

Precision and clarity are more important than sounding sophisticated.

Final Remarks

Scientific writing is part of your training as a researcher.

If you cannot explain your method clearly, you likely do not understand it deeply enough.

Write regularly. Revise carefully. Read good papers critically. Practice consistently.

Like programming and mathematics, writing is a skill developed through deliberate effort.
entry.summary: basic skills for writing scientific papers

entry.title: tutorials for quantum chemistry
entry.content:
Learning quantum chemistry requires both theoretical understanding and hands-on programming experience. Reading alone is not sufficient. Implementing methods yourself‚Äîeven simplified versions‚Äîwill dramatically deepen your understanding.

Below are several excellent resources that I strongly recommend.

Notes on Quantum Chemistry ‚Äì Professor David Sherrill

https://vergil.chemistry.gatech.edu

Under the Resources tab, there are comprehensive and clearly written notes covering Hartree‚ÄìFock theory, electron correlation, coupled cluster methods, and more. These are excellent references for both coursework and research.

You should not merely skim these notes. Work through the derivations, check intermediate steps, and try to reproduce key results on your own.

Programming Projects ‚Äì Professor Daniel Crawford

https://github.com/CrawfordGroup/ProgrammingProjects

This repository contains a series of structured programming projects that guide you through implementing:

  • Hartree-Fock
  • Second-order M√∏ller-Plesset perturbation theory (MP2)
  • Coupled cluster theory with singles and doubles (CCSD)
  • Configuration interaction singles (CIS)
  • Davidson-Liu algorithm for matrix diagonalization

These projects are particularly valuable because they bridge theory and implementation. If you can successfully complete these projects without copying solutions, you will have a solid foundation in electronic structure programming.

Computational Chemistry Tutorials ‚Äì Professor Fang Liu

https://liu-group.github.io

These tutorials provide practical introductions to running and analyzing computational chemistry calculations. They are especially useful for learning how to:

  • Set up calculations properly
  • Interpret output files
  • Connect theoretical methods with chemical insight

How to Use These Resources

A common mistake is to read passively or clone repositories without implementing anything yourself. That approach does not work. To truly master quantum chemistry:

  1. Read actively and derive equations yourself.
  2. Re-implement algorithms from scratch.
  3. Debug your own code.
  4. Compare your results with reference implementations.
  5. Repeat.

Struggling with derivations and debugging is not a sign of weakness ‚Äî it is part of the training process.

A Suggested Path

For students interested in method development:

  1. Review Hartree‚ÄìFock theory carefully.
  2. Implement a minimal RHF program.
  3. Add MP2 correlation.
  4. Study coupled cluster theory.
  5. Implement CCSD energy equations.
  6. Explore tensor libraries and performance optimization.

This progression will give you both conceptual clarity and practical skills.

Final Remark

Quantum chemistry is not mastered by watching lectures or reading slides. It is mastered by deriving, coding, testing, and refining.

Read carefully. Practice consistently. Be patient with yourself.

entry.title: setting up your development environment
entry.content:
As a quantum chemist, your daily workflow will include deriving equations, translating them into code, debugging, running large-scale computations, analyzing data, visualizing results, and writing papers. A well-configured development environment is essential for productivity.

This guide outlines a recommended setup for macOS and Linux systems. If you are currently using Windows, please install Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) and work inside a Linux environment whenever possible.

Although we illustrate the setup using macOS, almost all tools listed below also work on Linux.

Developer Tools

These tools form the foundation of your research workflow.

  • Xcode and Commond Line Tools: Required on macOS for compilers and development utilities.

  • Homebrew: The de facto package manager for macOS. Linux users should use their system package manager (e.g., apt for Ubuntu, dnf for Rocky Linux).

  • iTerm2: A powerful and customizable terminal emulator (macOS).

  • Oh My Zsh: A framework for managing your Zsh configuration. Combined with iTerm2, it significantly improves terminal usability.

  • Anaconda / Miniconda: A Python distribution for scientific computing. Installing Miniconda is usually sufficient and lighter weight. Also, please use Python 3.

  • Visual Studio Code (VS Code): A lightweight but powerful code editor. Install extensions for Python, C/C++, Git, and remote SSH development.

  • JetBrains IDEs (PyCharm, CLion): Excellent integrated development environments. Students can apply for a free academic license.

  • Vim: Learning a terminal-based editor is highly recommended. You may configure Vim yourself or use a preconfigured distribution (e.g., Spf13-Vim).

You may also consult curated software lists such as mac-dev-setup for additional tools.

Quantum Chemistry Packages

Below are widely used quantum chemistry packages. All are open-source or free for academic use.

  • PySCF: Python-based electronic structure package
  • OpenMolcas: Multiconfigurational quantum chemistry
  • ORCA: General-purpose quantum chemistry software
  • GAMESS: General ab initio quantum chemistry package
  • CFOUR: High-level coupled cluster methods
  • Psi4: Open-source ab initio quantum chemistry package
  • Forte: A Psi4 plugin focused on multireference methods

You are not expected to master all of these immediately. However, you should be comfortable installing, compiling (if necessary), and running at least one major package.

Visualization Tools

Visualization is an important skill. Clear molecular figures and orbital plots are essential for communication.

  • Avogadro: Molecular editor and visualizer
  • VMD: Molecular visualization software
  • PyMOL: Molecular graphics system (academic version available via Homebrew)
  • Matplotlib: Python plotting library for publication-quality figures

Reference Management

Choose one reference manager and learn to use it well:

  • Zotero
  • Mendeley
  • EndNote
  • Papers

Proper citation management will save you enormous time when writing papers.

Writing and Publishing

  • LaTeX (MacTeX / TeX Live): Required for professional scientific writing.

  • Adobe Illustrator or Inkscape: For polishing vector graphics before publication.

Final Remarks

Your computer is your primary research instrument. Investing time early in learning these skills will dramatically accelerate your research progress.

You may also want to check the awesome-mac list for other awesome macOS softwares.
entry.summary: setting up a Linux or macOS system for quantum chemistry research

entry.title: getting started
entry.content:
Modern quantum chemistry research is built on high-performance computing. In most cases, we run quantum chemistry softwares on multi-core machines with hundreds of gigabytes of memory.

These machines typically run a Linux operating system (e.g., Ubuntu or Rocky Linux). We access them remotely via SSH and work primarily in a terminal environment. Therefore, familiarity with Linux and command-line tools is an essential skill for every quantum chemist.

Below are excellent resources to help you get started:

  • Software Carpentry
  • The Missing Semester of Your CS Education (MIT)

At a minimum, you should be comfortable with:

  • Unix shell (file system navigation, scripting, job control)
  • Vim or another terminal-based text editor
  • Git for version control
  • Python and Numpy for scientific programming

Developing these skills early will make your research significantly more efficient and enjoyable.

If you are currently a Windows user, you are strongly encouraged to use Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) so that you can work in a Linux environment locally.
entry.summary: basic computer skills for quantum chemists
